etiology: Infected animals spread the disease through their urine. Places that attract large numbers of dogs and humans, like dog parks, tend to serve as the epicenter for infection. Contaminated water is the most common means of exposure, but contact with infected food or soil can also transmit lepto. Since the bacteria can live in the environment for months, you will need to keep prevention measures in mind even after the epidemic slows down.
epidemiology: Ask any veterinarian in Phoenix, AZ and chances are, they have encountered at least one case of canine leptospirosis. Also referred to as "lepto", this disease can pass between animals and humans. ... Places that attract large numbers of dogs and humans, like dog parks, tend to serve as the epicenter for infection.
treatment_challenges: Late discovery of the disease reduces survival chances. The vaccine remains in development, so it may not be effective for all cases. ... Also, the vaccination often works just for the short term.
